issue.title: GPU machines can be in a bad state
GPU machines can be in a bad state

content.raw:
Here's a backtrace across all threads of `gzserver` compiled in Debug mode from `gazebo_1.3`, when it was stuck during startup because the machine was in the bad state:

    Thread 4 (Thread 0x7fffe51ed700 (LWP 10771)):
    #0  0x00007ffff6bb552d in nanosleep () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0

    #3  0x00007ffff64a6ce9 in thread_proxy () from /usr/lib/libboost_thread.so.1.46.1

    #6  0x0000000000000000 in ?? ()
 
    Thread 3 (Thread 0x7fffe6006700 (LWP 10770)):
    #0  0x00007ffff5850353 in epoll_wait () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6

    #4  0x00007ffff64a6ce9 in thread_proxy () from /usr/lib/libboost_thread.so.1.46.1
    #5  0x00007ffff6bade9a in start_thread () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0

    Thread 2 (Thread 0x7fffe6807700 (LWP 10769)):

issue.title: GPU machines can be in a bad state

content.raw: I think I've seen something suspiciously similar on my laptop with some of the older precise linux kernels, it's possible 3.2.0-25 was one of them, maybe worth a try updating to newer kernels to see if this is fixed?
content.html: I think I've seen something suspiciously similar on my laptop with some of the older precise linux kernels, it's possible 3.2.0-25 was one of them, maybe worth a try updating to newer kernels to see if this is fixed?

issue.title: GPU machines can be in a bad state

content.raw: Upgrading the kernel seems worth a try.  Perhaps use the [procedure](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/DRC/DRCKickoffLaptops#Upgrade_the_kernel) that we did for the kickoff laptops.
content.html: Upgrading the kernel seems worth a try. Perhaps use the procedure that we did for the kickoff laptops.

issue.title: GPU machines can be in a bad state

content.raw:
Here's something that's allowed me to recover a machine that was in a bad state:

```
#!python
sudo service lightdm restart

```

Let me know if fails for you, as this is my best lead so far.
content.html:
Here's something that's allowed me to recover a machine that was in a bad state:

sudo service lightdm restart

Let me know if fails for you, as this is my best lead so far.

issue.title: GPU machines can be in a bad state

content.raw:
The 
```
#!python

sudo service lightdm restart
```
appears to be a red herring.

I have found another machine in bad state. After a reboot, I was able to run atlas simulations at about 0.6 realtime, and I let it run overnight. 

Running 
```
#!python

time glx_info
```
would give times of either 1.5 secs (as expected) or 20secs (too slow).  90% of the tiem I would get bad results. glzxgears would give fps of 0.1 for a minute or two, but those would pick up after a minute or so (1700+).

After another reboot of the same machine, I get glsinfo running within 4.5 sec consistently with good simulations.

Conclusion: Rebooting helps, problems don't seem to "come back" once the machine is in a good state.

To be continued...
content.html:
The 

sudo service lightdm restart

appears to be a red herring.

I have found another machine in bad state. After a reboot, I was able to run atlas simulations at about 0.6 realtime, and I let it run overnight.

Running 

time glx_info

would give times of either 1.5 secs (as expected) or 20secs (too slow). 90% of the tiem I would get bad results. glzxgears would give fps of 0.1 for a minute or two, but those would pick up after a minute or so (1700+).

After another reboot of the same machine, I get glsinfo running within 4.5 sec consistently with good simulations.

Conclusion: Rebooting helps, problems don't seem to "come back" once the machine is in a good state.

To be continued...

issue.title: GPU machines can be in a bad state

content.raw: With the switch to SoftLayer for the VRC, this issue is no longer relevant.  Until we hear from non-/post-VRC users who encounter this issue on AWS machines, we won't work on it.
content.html: With the switch to SoftLayer for the VRC, this issue is no longer relevant. Until we hear from non-/post-VRC users who encounter this issue on AWS machines, we won't work on it.
